title: Behavioral Observational Pain Scale (BOPS) for Post-Op Pediatric Pain
description: Quantifies post-operative pain for children aged 1-7 years using observational behavioral indicators

parameters.name: facial_expression
parameters.description: Assessment of child's facial expression as an indicator of pain
options: 2 - Negative facial expression, grimace, distorted face

parameters.name: verbalization
parameters.description: Assessment of child's verbal expressions and vocalizations
options: 1 - Completely quiet, sobbing and/or complaining but not because of pain
2 - Crying, screaming and/or complaining about pain

parameters.name: body_position
parameters.description: Assessment of child's body positioning and movement patterns
options: 0 - Inactive, laying, relaxed with all extremities or sitting, walking
1 - Restless movements, shifting fashion and/or touching wound or wound area
2 - Lying rigid and/or drawn up with arms and legs to the body

result.name: bops_score
result.description: BOPS score from 0 (no pain behaviors) to 6 (maximum pain behaviors)

ranges.description: Little to no pain behaviors observed
ranges.interpretation: Child demonstrates minimal or no pain behaviors. Continue routine monitoring and comfort measures. Consider non-pharmacological comfort interventions such as positioning, parental presence, or distraction techniques.

Child demonstrates significant pain behaviors requiring intervention. Consider analgesia administration according to institutional protocols. Reassess pain score 15-20 minutes after IV analgesics or 30-45 minutes after oral/rectal analgesics.

references: Hesselgard K, Larsson S, Romner B, Strömblad LG, Reinstrup P. Validity and reliability of the Behavioural Observational Pain Scale for postoperative pain measurement in children 1-7 years of age. Pediatr Crit Care Med. 2007 Mar;8(2):102-8.
von Baeyer CL, Spagrud LJ. Systematic review of observational (behavioral) measures of pain for children and adolescents aged 3 to 18 years. Pain. 2007 Jan;127(1-2):140-50.
Duhn LJ, Medves JM. A systematic integrative review of infant pain assessment tools. Adv Neonatal Care. 2004 Jun;4(3):126-40.
formula: BOPS Score = Facial Expression (0-2) + Verbalization (0-2) + Body Position (0-2)
notes: Designed specifically for children aged 1-7 years in post-operative settings
Scores ≥3 indicate need for analgesia consideration
Should be assessed every 3 hours routinely
Reassess 15-20 minutes after IV analgesics or 30-45 minutes after oral/rectal analgesics
Excellent interrater reliability (κw 0.86 to 0.95 for each item)
Strong concurrent validity with CHEOPS scale (rs = 0.871, p < 0.001)
Simple scoring system makes it easy to incorporate in postoperative units
Developed in 1996 at Neurointensive Care Unit in Lund, Sweden
